messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Early sukashi tsuba attribution
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Jim for your encouraging reply ! And ofcourse for taking the time to explain the Akasaka situation in a little more detail. Much much appreciated ! Now
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Jim for your encouraging reply ! And ofcourse for taking the time
to explain the Akasaka situation in a little more detail. Much much
appreciated !

Now back to the books for me ...................... I still have an
awful lot to learn, but I enjoy it and that is important.

- Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Verzonden: zondag 29 juni 2003 7:20
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Early sukashi tsuba attribution


Matt,
Very good calls -- well done. However, I have to say that Akasaka would
be difficult to defend. That mokko shape would be very unusual for
Akasaka. Their seppa dai tended to be more narrow and were often
somewhat to very pointed at the top in the early generations. The broad
shape would be, again unusual. They didn't normally do quadrilateral
symmetry like that and the hitsuana are also not typical, although
Tadashige often made "dovetails" for (often non-existent) sekigane like
we see here on the kozuka ana side. Akasaka construction often used a
hard, smooth kawagane that looks quite different from the texture of the
iron on this guard. The rim is usually very round in the early
generations.

BUT... there are a bunch of signed Akasaka guards by later generations
that are not obviously in Akasaka style based on the carving, motifs and
even inlay. It's an interesting study. The first Akasaka died around
1657, FWIW. Pretty sure it's not an Akasaka piece, though.

Writing opinions is a great way to learn. Keep it up and don't worry
about the feet. You did good.

Jim


This is my totally uninformed novice opinion. So feel free to put your
foot in if I am way off base here. Anyway with that disclaimer gone
here goes (I have to try sometime haha)

My first guess would be Kyoto for the first tsuba, second guess
Akasaka,
whatever it is dating to the (early) 1600's

Second tsuba: I am inclined to agree with Tom, early simple Onin.

How did I do ?

- Matt

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Hi Ron;

My Onin is just under 2.omm in thickness, and 77.0mm in diameter.

John
----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Polansky
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, June 28, 2003 8:28 PM

Jim/John/Gents:

Thanks very much for the help!
Kyo-Shoami it is on the sukashi guard.

On the other, Onin makes absolute sense..and the pics of John's
tsuba look right on (plate and ring)
Btw, the rim is 3.5 mm and is uniform on the Onin tsuba..

Thanks again,
Ron P.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Early sukashi tsuba attribution
messages.msgSnippet: Matt, Very good calls -- well done.  However, I have to say that Akasaka would be difficult to defend.  That mokko shape would be very unusual for Akasaka.
messages.messageBody:
Matt,
Very good calls -- well done. However, I have to say that Akasaka would be difficult to defend. That mokko shape would be very unusual for Akasaka. Their seppa dai tended to be more narrow and were often somewhat to very pointed at the top in the early generations. The broad shape would be, again unusual. They didn't normally do quadrilateral symmetry like that and the hitsuana are also not typical, although Tadashige often made "dovetails" for (often non-existent) sekigane like we see here on the kozuka ana side. Akasaka construction often used a hard, smooth kawagane that looks quite different from the texture of the iron on this guard. The rim is usually very round in the early generations.

BUT... there are a bunch of signed Akasaka guards by later generations that are not obviously in Akasaka style based on the carving, motifs and even inlay. It's an interesting study. The first Akasaka died around 1657, FWIW. Pretty sure it's not an Akasaka piece, though.

Writing opinions is a great way to learn. Keep it up and don't worry about the feet. You did good.

Jim


This is my totally uninformed novice opinion. So feel free to put your
foot in if I am way off base here. Anyway with that disclaimer gone
here goes (I have to try sometime haha)

My first guess would be Kyoto for the first tsuba, second guess Akasaka,
whatever it is dating to the (early) 1600's

Second tsuba: I am inclined to agree with Tom, early simple Onin.

How did I do ?

- Matt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Early sukashi tsuba attribution
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, Probably not Kyo-Shoami given the lack of marubori elements and/or nunome zogan.  Shoami if Edo period or Ko-Shoami if pre-Edo -- at least that is my
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
Probably not Kyo-Shoami given the lack of marubori elements and/or nunome zogan. Shoami if Edo period or Ko-Shoami if pre-Edo -- at least that is my interpretation of your guard based on my knowledge of the current kantei conventions.

3.5 mm is rather thick for early Onin work, although the surface of the plate does look old. John's guard looks younger than yours in both the plate and the inlay style.
Jim

Jim/John/Gents:

Thanks very much for the help!
Kyo-Shoami it is on the sukashi guard.

On the other, Onin makes absolute sense..and the pics of John's
tsuba look right on (plate and ring)
Btw, the rim is 3.5 mm and is uniform on the Onin tsuba..

Thanks again,
Ron P.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Early sukashi tsuba attribution
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Ron; I think Jim is right on the money. I have a tsuba very similar to your Onin tsuba but it has a constellation in negative sukashi with the brass outline
messages.messageBody:
Hi Ron;

I think Jim is right on the money.

I have a tsuba very similar to your Onin tsuba but it has a constellation in negative sukashi with the brass outline just as Jim described. her is the link,

http://www3.telus.net/sword/sword/index.htm/My%20Webs6/tsb1gal.htm

John
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, June 28, 2003 9:34 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Early sukashi tsuba attribution


Ron,
The broad seppa dai and the shape of the hitsuana are seen in Owari tsuba. The style of the sukashi is more like Kyo work, though. It's difficult to judge iron from photographs, but it doesn't look typically Owari. I've seen guards that looked quite like Owari be judged as Shoami because of uncertainty over the lack of some classic characteristic or other. Some of these sukashi pieces can be very difficult to pigeonhole with confidence because they share characteristics of Kyo and Owari. My guess is that your guard would be attributed to Shoami. Probably early Edo period or a bit older.

The other guard is interesting. Some of that type have plates like Kamakura bori and have a simple carving around the rim. Others have plates more like Onin guards. Both types can have a simple ring or two of brass inlay. I don't think I've seen an example that has the rim hammered like yours, but aesthetically it seems like the same idea as the carved decoration seen on others.

The style of the plate, the shape of the kozuka ana and the simple inlay decoration would all point to an Onin attribution. How thick is it? Probably mid Muromachi at least.

Jim


Gentlemen:

I really have problems with attribution on these early tsuba:
http://www.nihontophile.com/Suk1.jpg
http://www.nihontophile.com/Suk2.jpg
http://www.nihontophile.com/Suk3.jpg
Tsuba is 7.2 tall x 6.9 cm wide; 4 mm thick at the mimi.
I first thought Ko-Shoami because of the fine sukashi work.
But it looks Owari (and has bones in the rim). However it is on the
small side..which would place it late but it looks early and has
obviously been mounted many times.
What about Kyo-Shoami?
(perhaps some day I will get it down.....:)

Also this tsuba has given me a fit as to attribution/age:
http://www.nihontophile.com/html/gallery.html

Any help would be much appreciated.

Kind regards,
Ron P.

messages.msgSnippet: Ron, The broad seppa dai and the shape of the hitsuana are seen in Owari tsuba.  The style of the sukashi is more like Kyo work, though.  It s difficult to
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
The broad seppa dai and the shape of the hitsuana are seen in Owari tsuba. The style of the sukashi is more like Kyo work, though. It's difficult to judge iron from photographs, but it doesn't look typically Owari. I've seen guards that looked quite like Owari be judged as Shoami because of uncertainty over the lack of some classic characteristic or other. Some of these sukashi pieces can be very difficult to pigeonhole with confidence because they share characteristics of Kyo and Owari. My guess is that your guard would be attributed to Shoami. Probably early Edo period or a bit older.

The other guard is interesting. Some of that type have plates like Kamakura bori and have a simple carving around the rim. Others have plates more like Onin guards. Both types can have a simple ring or two of brass inlay. I don't think I've seen an example that has the rim hammered like yours, but aesthetically it seems like the same idea as the carved decoration seen on others.

The style of the plate, the shape of the kozuka ana and the simple inlay decoration would all point to an Onin attribution. How thick is it? Probably mid Muromachi at least.

Jim

I first thought Ko-Shoami because of the fine sukashi work.
